trenches during WW1 and he blamed the fact on Jewish opposition to the war, 
which prevented quick victories.

Moreover, these were not only Hitler's beliefs. Christians have been 
manufacturing conspiracy theories about the Jews since the first century. 
Look up things like "blood libel" and "the wandering Jew". Christians have 
also performed periodic Jew cleansings in Europe although they have had 
smaller scope than the Holocaust. Hitler's beliefs actually were mainstream 
and that's why he was able to attain power. There are even examples of 
places like Austria where the local population started lynching the Jews 
before the Nazi troops arrived. You literally have to hold that "Almost 50% 
of Europe were psychopaths" during WW2 to defend your thesis.

It's worse though, because if you go back 100 years more, you'll find that 
most countries in Europe had anti-Jewish legislation as official policy. 
For example, even relatively modern constitutions like that of Norway, from 
1814, has as its second statement, after declaring that Norway is a 
sovereign nation, that Jews and Jesuits don't have access to the kingdom. 
And that's viewed as a very progressive constitution in many ways. The idea 
that there was something special about Hitler's psychology is laughable and 
just involves avoiding taking responsibility for the fact that produced the 
holocaust - 2000 years of Christian antisemitism, lies and slander against 
the Jews.

comments.text:
+Michael Idarecis " However in the last 7 years have a different 
understanding not founded on choice."

No. You obviously are a latecomer to this debate. You should probably look 
up the term "Compatibilism". It goes back to the Stoics in ancient Greece - 
at least(it's probably the first view of responsibility and agency humans 
had, because the animals we evolved from most certainly don't worry about 
free will). Sam Harris etc add no new thoughts to that discussion beyond 
the connection to neuroscience.

Your obsession with free choice is actually a problem that doesn't arise in 
any other context than monotheisms with judging creator gods who also 
claims to be moral. That is, some interpretations of Christianity and 
Islam(Ones that don't just embrace determinism and a divine command theory 
of morality). That situation creates a problem, because the apparent 
determinism of the natural world seems to not make humans morally 
responsible vs the God who set it all in motion. That's the origin of the 
logical contradiction "libertarian free will". It is not a property of 
religion in general, just your type of religion. Which, amusingly, is just 
the kind of religion that historically has led the charge for worldwide 
domination and imperialism. Hardly a good moral role model even in practice.

In any case, humans make choices under naturalism as well. We just 
recognize that those choices are a consequence of natural laws operating on 
already existing personality constraints in people's brains. So if you 
decide to rape a little girl merely because the image of said little girl 
falls on your retina, we are going to conclude that you are a dangerous 
organism, because you exhibit that behavior and because you made that 
choice. In a sense, we'd be punishing you because you are "you" and the 
"you" makes such decisions.The determinism means we can be confident that 
you would repeat your actions unless we intervene in some way. If we really 
believed your past actions have no relationship to your future actions, or 
what's going on around you, then we'd have no reason to punish you or 
praise you for anything. Under the deterministic model, we do this to 
encourage or discourage your behavior though, such that you meet with 
desirable or undesirable consequences which will feed back into your 
decision making apparatus and causing you to learn to behave better.

comments.text:
+Ivan Gushkov You're overthinking this for the purposes of this question. I 
mean yes, you're right - if you actually were in that situation, you'd 
probably have to think of those things. But those issues are totally 
orthogonal to this thought experiment. The actual point of this experiment 
is to determine whether or not you'd kill Hitler as a baby if you knew you 
could get away with it, assuming that that would prevent millions of deaths 
and turn out better for everyone. That's the spirit the question is posed 
in. It isn't a game theory, time traveler type question about changes the 
course of the future, altering reality in profound and unforseen ways, etc.

So, for the sake of this experiment, you're just supposed to assume that 
killing Hitler would save millions of lives and would be good for the 
future. In that case, would you kill the baby? That's the point of the 
question.
comments.author: Michael L

comments.text:
But do you know what happens if you kill him? Think about it. Was Hitler 
that special as an individual? The thing is Germany was ripe for a dictator 
like Hitler. If Hitler died at the age of 1, there would have been plenty 
who thought like he did. The Germans needed someone to blame for the 
situation they were in, and the Jew were perfect candidates. Hitler was 
just the final drop.
 But let us suppose that you manage to avoid a conflict, Germany gets out 
of the shitty situation and all is dandy. Yes? Well the thing is we dont 
know. Humanity learned very important lessons from WW2, especially the 
Holocaust. What if preventing the Holocaust causes an even bigger Holocaust 
say in 2015?
 I am in no way in support of Hitler or what he did. I am just saying that 
we should not mess with history. If i knew *for sure* that the effects of 
my actions would cause *only positive* things down the line, then the 
answer is yes i would kill him and i will go in jail for it if i have to. 
But we dont know the outcome. Best not to play with history...

Kevin Dutton is attempting to normalize psychopaths and psychopathic 
behavior. His scenarios are ridiculous and even he admits that they are 
absurd. He presents the scenario that psychopaths make good leaders 
because, lacking conscience, they are able to make the decisions the rest 
of us cannot, because we are constrained by conscience and morality.

That's precisely the point, Kevin. A cursory study of history will show 
conclusively that psychopathic leaders recreate the chaos in their own 
minds, and externalize this chaos onto their followers, with disastrous 
results for those they lead, and for themselves.

The point is, Kevin, that we don't need to approach psychopathy by creating 
impossible scenarios. We have enough real-life scenarios of psychopaths, 
and how the choices they have made have left entire societies in ruin.

Just name one single, solitary psychopath whose behavior resulted in a 
positive outcome, a net gain for society. Just one will do.

If you have ever been the victim of a psychopath, you know these people are 
incorrigible and incapable of being "cured" or "helped." They leave a trail 
of destruction wherever they go.They need to be held accountable for their 
criminal behavior, not glorified.﻿

top_comment.text:
In order for me to even consider taking a life, the person in question 
would have to be just like a stereotypical psychopathic super villain. I 
have a set of general questions that I ask myself asked in order for me to 
consider taking a life.

1. Can any real good come from their existence?
2. Can they possibly be redeemed?
3. Could they be effectively imprisoned?
4. Does their continued existence pose no threat to liberty?
5. Is there a way they would be willing to unconditionally step down from 
power?

If I had answered "yes" to any of the above questions, then I couldn't even 
consider taking a life. How many of you are truly like that? I want to 
know.﻿

comments.text:
The concern you showed is the reason i dont normally use the word 
ultilitarianism.

The reason i think that ultilitarianism still holds  up is that its the 
only sensible way to speak about morality.

What can we care about? the only thing that truly matters is our emotions 
and the emotions of others. we can call that wellbeing.  there is nothing 
other than wellbeing that we can care about. if something  happends that 
does not influence anyones emotions in any way that that event is not 
important morally.

since there is nothing to talk about morally other than emotions we must 
maximalize the good ones and minimalize the best ones.

on the example you gave, killing one person to save 10. it would not 
neccesarily be good morally to do so. the consuquence is not simply 10-1=9. 
it is also that you would go trough life feeling like a murderer. or that 
people would feel like anyone could just sacrifice them for the greater 
good. there are more complex concerns here that are best considered in 
terms of good emotions and bad emotions.

it is also true that we should care about everyones emotions just as much 
as our own, however it is not realistic to expect anyone to constantly 
behave in such a way. but when we make the really important disisions, when 
we write laws and decide wheter or not to go to wars, that is when we need 
to think in such terms.

long story short: emotions are all we have to care about, and we want as 
much of the good ones as possible.
comments.author: Aizsaule

Utilitariansim requires you to kill a person to save another ten people.

comments.text:
+BecomingMike
> The whole point of the scenario is that those options are not available.

And that's exactly what's wrong with these kinds of "moral dilemma" 
hypotheticals.

You can't simply say "option X is not available" or "assume there is not 
doubt about claim Y".
You would have to construct a detailed, *realistic* scenario with enough 
"backstory" to cover all follow-up questions, to explain *why* you are in 
that situation, *why* certain options are not possible, *why* you should 
believe any particular observation to be true, etc.

*Only then* could someone meaningfully base any kind of moral reasoning on 
your scenario. And most likely, it would turn out that in this 
realistically fleshed-out form, the scenario is no longer of a "dilemma" at 
all.

Which is, of course, the reason why philosophers who like to pose 
hypotheticals don't do that. They rely on obfuscation via logically 
inconsistent/incomplete scenarios to creater the illusion of an 
"impossible-to-solve dilemma".
comments.author: eshah100

No way in hell would I kill a baby, even to save my own life I'm not going 
to kill a baby, I couldn't live with myself having done so. Nor would I 
kill one person to save five, or any other number in the scenario you 
suggested. The only morally justifiable reason for taking another human 
life is in defense of my own life or to save another from being murdered in 
my presence, in which case I would absolutely intervene without hesitation. 
The only life I have (or should have) the right to end is my own.
During World War II Churchill allowed a British town to be bombed when he 
had advance knowledge of the impending attack because if he had evacuated 
the town or added to its defenses, the Germans might realize that their 
codes had been broken and that the allies were able to intercept 
communications they thought were secure. In one way, it was most certainly 
the right decision at the time, but personally I would have evacuated the 
town or defended it, codes be damned.
But if I had been an adviser to Churchill I would not have tried to 
persuade him to do anything differently either, I would have been silent or 
neutral. I don't have as difficult time with others making these 
utilitarian types of decisions in such a context, but for myself, I simply 
wouldn't be able to allow that town to remain in the dark about the 
imminent danger for the sake of protecting code-breaking capability. There 
is a chance the Germans might have wrote it off as luck, bad timing, etc. 
Of course, that's what I say now, if I saw that kind of destruction and 
death every day for a while, it might be a lot easier.
I'm no moral guide or teacher, nor would I claim to be or presume to 
lecture others on tough choices like this, but dammit, killing is WRONG. 
Especially killing babies. Even baby Hitler.﻿

top_comment.text:
While it seems like the obvious answer to stop Hitler in some way and 
prevent the horrors of the Holocast... in truth, Hitler's actions were a 
much needed event in the wake of modern history.

Hear me out, it has nothing to do with Anti-Semitism or hatred or lesser 
peoples.

Hitler's actions were a wake-up call for the world, in showing just how 
dangerous it was for any one person or group to have complete control and 
allowing them to have free reign, and to allow bigotry and hatred to run 
amok and unrestrained. It mattered little that people like the Jews, 
innocents themselves, were the victims, if it weren't Hitler, someone else 
may have come along and done the same to them or to someone else on a 
similarly massive level... or worse, they wouldn't have done so to the 
point it garnered the reaction the Holocaust did.

If so, they would have never prompted the creation of things like the 
Geneva Convention, and dictate what can or cannot be done in war, and set 
in stage the modern era where countries have to answer to one another or 
face alienation from the entire world.

The world began truly policing it's own following the atrocities of the 
Second World War, and the combination of the Holocaust and the horrific 
after-effects of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki were enough 
to prompt the world's undivided attention. It made them realize that enough 
was enough, and a line had to be drawn in what was reasonable in conflict.

The people who died from the Holocaust and from the War did not die in 
vain, beyond Hitler failing in conquering the world, their deaths brought 
to light the darker side of humanity and forced us all to confront it, 
whether we liked it or not.﻿

top_comment.text:
If I did know that the baby would grow up to be Adolf Hitler, would I kill 
him? No.
Assuming that I know enough of the future to see what this baby would 
become, I would also have the clairvoyance to see what would become, if the 
baby DID NOT live.

I'll give a fictitious example. The question was addressed in the game 
franchise Command & Conquer: Red Alert. Einstein invents a time machine, 
and erases Hitler from history. The disruption of European powers allows 
the rise of Joseph Stalin, and his takeover of Europe. There's some info on 
Stalin on his Wiki page http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_stalin

But long story short, without Hitler's Nazi Germany to stand in the way, it 
is probable that the USSR would have at least attempted to invade the rest 
of Europe, never mind what the USSR actually DID invade around that time, 
and the massive famine that resulted from Stalin's forced conversion of the 
USSR from an agrarian economy into an industrialized one. Think of how much 
worse it would have been if Stalin was able to continue his conquest.

Of course, if Hitler didn't persecute the Jews, then we're faced with a 
different scenario, The modern nation of Israel would never have been 
formed, we wouldn't have Jews and Christians squatting in the middle east, 
provoking much retaliation from the Islamic community. Not to say that 
Islamist extremism wouldn't still be a problem, it would just be less of 
one. The USSR would probably do a good job of keeping Islam out of Europe 
entirely, with the cost of trading one tyranny for another.

Of course, it is mere speculation. It is impossible to predict reliably how 
one party would have reacted without the other to keep the first in check.

So we're left with one evil, and another just as bad. The moral of the 
story is: Don't try to change history, but learn from it, so you don't 
repeat it.﻿

captions.text:
When we talk about the trolley problem, actually
research has been done on the kinds of people

who are willing to shove the fat guy over
the rails. And what that research has uncovered

is that these people tend to be utilitarian's
in our society, okay. They tend to be people

who are able to get the job done, who are
less morally squeamish.

Now I've actually presented a variation of
this dilemma to various psychopaths. I'll

give an example of what the variation of the
dilemma is. Imagine that you are a transplant

surgeon. And you have five patients all in
need of a transplant, heart, lungs, whatever.

Okay? And they're all gonna die if they don't
get that transplant, but there are no matching
donors available.

Just by chance, a young traveler happens to
walk past your surgery one day for just a

regular check-up. And it turns out, hypothetically,
that he is a direct match for all five, okay.

Now imagine that you are the transplant surgeon.
Imagine if there was no come back to you,

if that traveler somehow disappeared, okay.
Would it be right to kill that young traveler

in order to take his five organs to transplant
them into your five patients?

Now, most people -- again it's the five and
one life score. It's exactly like the trolley

problem. But most people would say absolutely
not. No, that's just not right. It's ethically

not right to kill that person. But I've given
this to psychopathic killers and they've said,

well actually, you know what? Imagine if you
were the families of those five guys. One

life lost, is it really that bad when you're
saving five others? What if that guy was an

evil terrorist? And the five guys who needed
to transplants were peace workers or aid workers,
for instance. Would that make it any different?

Now, these are kinds of -- not exactly that
-- but these are kinds of scenarios, these

are kinds of decisions that world leaders
and politicians have to grapple with. Here's

another little one to conjure with. Imagine
that you were, hypothetically, left in a room
with a newborn baby, okay.

And you were left in that room for ten minutes
with that newborn baby. And I told you -- and

you have to believe this is true -- that that
newborn baby will grow one day into Adolph

Hitler, okay. And I told you that there would
be no moral comeback, no legal comebacks on

you were you to kill that baby with a pillow
and walk out of that room.

Now, what would you do? Would you kill that
baby and save millions of lives further on

down the line in history? Or would you not
be able to do it? These are moral conundrums,

which are kind of played out in everyday life.
I'm obviously reducing these to absurdities.

But these are the kinds of decisions on a
lesser level that you have to make if you're
a politician or if you're a world leader.

Sending anyone out in to battle knowing that
there's a chance that they might not come

back, committing thousands of troops to a
war is something that not many people can
carry lightly on their conscience.

And if you look at psychopathic traits, actually,
you know, psychopathic traits are pretty well

represented in politicians and world leaders.
You think about it. You know, politicians

and leaders have to deal with all sorts of
nasty kinds of crisis during their administrations,

anything from the threats from rouge states
to natural disasters like hurricanes or floods.

Also, though, they have to be pretty confident
to run for office at all. They have to be

very good at presenting themselves in a certain
light. And they have to be very persuasive

and manipulative. I mean, one senior UK politician,
who should for obvious reasons remain nameless,

had a great quote. And he said to me, "You
know, in politics the only way to know who's

stabbing you in the back is to see their reflection
in the eyes of the person stabbing you from
the front."

That's a great kind of quote, which, for me,
sums up that kind of snakes and ladders game.

Every man for himself, cut throat, kind of
existence that characterizes politics I would

say probably across the board in most nations
of the world.

title: Would You Kill Baby Hitler? (And Other Psychopathic Musings, with Kevin Dutton)
